## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 358, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 586, 593, 601]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 601, 606, 616]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 609, 646]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 646, 756, 661]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 661, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 74, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Each year, the value of a certain rare stamp increases by \(5\%\) of its value at the beginning of the year. A collector bought the stamp for \(\) 10 000$ at the beginning of 2005. Find its value at the beginning of 2015 correct to the nearest \(\) 100.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The sum of the first \(n\) terms of an arithmetic progression is \(\frac{1}{2} n(3n + 7)\). Find the 1st term and the common difference of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 299, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 91, 573, 128]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{area~of~region~}P}{\mathrm{area~of~region~}Q},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 131, 561, 149]]<|/det|>
giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 720, 92]]<|/det|>
(i) Show that the equation \(\cos 2x(\tan^2 2x + 3) + 3 = 0\) can be expressed as

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 100, 609, 119]]<|/det|>
\[2\cos^{2}2x + 3\cos 2x + 1 = 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 73, 722, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\cos 2x(\tan^2 2x + 3) + 3 = 0\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant x \leqslant 180^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}:x\mapsto c + d\sin x\) for \(x\in \mathbb{R}\). The range of g is given by \(-4\leqslant \mathrm{g}(x)\leqslant 10\). Find the values of the constants \(c\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Points \(A\) and \(B\) lie on the curve \(y = x^{2} - 4x + 7\). Point \(A\) has coordinates (4, 7) and \(B\) is the stationary point of the curve. The equation of a line \(L\) is \(y = mx - 2\), where \(m\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 767, 139]]<|/det|>
In the case where \(L\) passes through the mid-point of \(AB\), find the value of \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 667, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(m\) for which \(L\) does not meet the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 816, 92]]<|/det|>
Given that the curve passes through the point (6, 2), find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 83, 665, 269]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 920, 349]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a trapezium \(OABC\) in which \(OA\) is parallel to \(CB\). The position vectors of \(A\) and \(B\) relative to the origin \(O\) are given by \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -2 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 363, 154, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 363, 390, 381]]<|/det|>
Show that angle \(OAB\) is \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 363, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 581, 695]]<|/det|>
The magnitude of \(\overrightarrow{CB}\) is three times the magnitude of \(\overrightarrow{OA}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 706, 154, 724]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 706, 395, 724]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 705, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 84, 685, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 295, 920, 330]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \sqrt{(5x - 1)}\) and the normal to the curve at the point \(P\) (2, 3). This normal meets the \(x\)-axis at \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 342, 156, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 342, 455, 359]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the normal at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 342, 920, 359]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 695, 92]]<|/det|>
